statement.tex: %text Show that the relation S in the set $A=\{x\in\mathbb{Z}:0 \le x\le 12\}$ given by $S=\{(a,b): a, b\in \mathbb{Z}, |a-b|$ is divisible by $4$\} is an equivalence relation. Find the set of all elements related to 1. %

step.context: %text Are the following pairs a valid examples of $S=\{(a,b): a, b\in \mathbb{Z}, |a-b|$ is divisible by $4$\} in the set $A=\{x\in\mathbb{Z}:0 \le x\le 12\}$? %
step.reason: \begin{align} (1,5)&=|1-5|=4 \\ (12,4)&=|12-4|=8 \\ (5,11)&=|5-11|=6 \\ (2, 6)&=|2-6|=4 \\ (3,15)&=|3-15|=12 \end{align} \\ %text Of the above, $6$ is not divisible by $4$ and $15$ is not a member of set A. Therefore, all pairs above are valid examples of the relation S, with the exception of $(5,11)$ and $(3, 15)$. %

step.context: %text What conditions must a relation satisfy for it to be an equivalence relation? %
step.tex: %text It must be reflexive, symmetric and transitive. %
%text It must be reflexive, but not symmetric or transitive. %
step.reason: %text An equivalence relation must be reflexive, symmetric and transitive. Next, what are these and how do we go about proving them? %

step.context: %text Is the relation $S=\{(a,b): a, b\in \mathbb{Z}, |a-b|$ is divisible by $4$\} in the set $A=\{x\in\mathbb{Z}:0 \le x\le 12\}$ reflexive? In other words, does $(a, a)\in A$ and is $|a-a|$ divisible by $4$? %
step.tex: %text Yes, $(a,a)$ is reflexive since $|a-a|$ is divisible by $4$. %
step.reason: %text $|a-a|=0$ which is divisible by $4$, therefore relation $S$ is reflexive. %

step.context: %text Is the relation $S=\{(a,b): a, b\in \mathbb{Z}, |a-b|$ is divisible by $4$\} in the set $A=\{x\in\mathbb{Z}:0 \le x\le 12\}$ symmetric? In other words, does $(a, b)=(b, a)$? %
step.tex: %text Yes, $(a,b)=(b,a)$ therefore the relation is symmetric. %
step.reason: %text $(a,b)=|a-b|$ which is obviously equal to $|b-a|$, therefore if $(a,b)\in S$ is true then $(b,a) \in S$ is also true and the relation is symmetric. %

step.context: %text Is the relation $S=\{(a,b): a, b\in \mathbb{Z}, |a-b|$ is divisible by $4$\} in the set $A=\{x\in\mathbb{Z}:0 \le x\le 12\}$ transitive? In other words, if $(a, b)\in S$ and $(b,c)\in S$, does it mean $(a,c)\in S$ is also true? %
step.tex: %text If $(a,b)\in S$ and $(b,c)\in S$ we cannot presume $(c,a)\in S$. %
step.reason: \begin{align} (a,b) &= |a-b| \\ (b,c) &= |b-c| \\ (c,a) &= |c-a| \\ \end{align} \\ %text If $|a-b|=4k$ and $|b-c|=4l$, then $a=b\pm 4k$ and $c=b\pm 4l$. Therefore, $|c-a|$ must be divisible by $4$. Moreover, since $(a,b)\in A$, their difference would also be $\in A$. Therefore, $(a,b)$ is transitive. %

step.context: %text $S=\{(a,b): a, b\in \mathbb{Z}, |a-b|$ is divisible by $4$\} For the relation S in the set $A=\{x\in\mathbb{Z}:0 \le x\le 12\}$ find the set of all elements related to 1. In other words, find the set of $(1, a)$ for which $|1-a|$ is divisible by $4$. %
step.reason: \left\{5, 9\right\} \\ %text Only the above elements related with $1$ are part of the set A.. %
